facts.text: Writ Petition No. 379 of 1974 filed under article 32 of the Constitution of India

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 379 of 1974. Petition under article 32 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: District Magistrate, 24-Parganas, made detention order dated 29th December 1973 under section 3(1) and (2) of MISA 1971 to prevent petitioner from acting prejudicial to public order

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate, 24-Parganas, by an order dated 29th December, 1973 made under sub-section 1 read with subsection 2 of section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 directed that the petitioner be detained as be was satisfied that with a view to preventing the petitioner from acting in a manner pre- judicial to the maintenance of public order it was necessary to detain him.

facts.text: District Magistrate reported detention order to State Government on 2nd January 1974

anchor.surface_text: The fact of the making of the order of detention was reported by the District Magistrate to the State Government on 2nd January, 1974

facts.text: State Government approved detention order on 8th January 1974

anchor.surface_text: and the State Government, by an order dated 8th January, 1974, approved the order of detention.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on 18th January 1974 pursuant to detention order and served grounds immediately

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the order of detention, ,the petitioner was arrested on 18th January, 1974 and immediately ,on his arrest he was served with the grounds on which the order of detention was made.

facts.text: Grounds of detention refer to incident on night of 25/26 June 1973 where petitioner and associates raided house of Ananta Keyal, looted cash and ornaments, fired indiscriminately causing death of Ananta Kayal and Ajit Kayal, assaulted inmates, created panic

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of detention referred only to the incident as forming the basis of arriving at the subjective satisfaction ,,as regards the necessity for detention of the petitioner and that incident was in the following terms On the night of 25/26-6-73 at about 00.1 hrs. you along with your associates being armed with lethal. weapons including fire Arms raided the house of Ananta Keyal of Naitala under Diamond Harbour P.S. and looted away cash, ornaments etc. At the time of operation you fixed from your fire arms indiscriminately disregarding human lives and their safety. As a result, the house owner Ananta Kayal and his close door neighbour Ajit Kayal sustained grievous gun shot injuries on their persons, Subsequently both of them ,expired in Diamond Harbour Hospital. You also brutally assulated some of the inmates of the house of occurrence. Your action created such panic in the locality and the local people felt a sense of insecurity. Thus you acted in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Petitioner made representation against detention on 29th January 1974

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner made a representation against the order of detention on 29th January, 1974

facts.text: State Government considered and rejected petitioner's representation on 31st January 1974

anchor.surface_text: but it was companysidered and rejected by the State Government on 31st January, 1974.

facts.text: State Government submitted petitioner's case with representation to Advisory Board

anchor.surface_text: The State Government thereafter submitted the case of the petitioner to the Advisory Board along ,with his representation

facts.text: Advisory Board heard petitioner, considered representation, reported sufficient cause for detention on 6th March 1974

anchor.surface_text: and the Advisory Board, after bearing the ,petitioner and taking into account the representation made by him, ,made a report to the State Government on 6th March, 1974 stating that in its opinion there was sufficient cause for the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention on 14th March 1974

anchor.surface_text: The State Government accordingly passed an order dated 14th March, 1974 companyfirming the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: Petition challenging detention submitted from jail

anchor.surface_text: This detention is challenged by the petitioner in the present petition which has been submitted from jail.

facts.text: Criminal case filed against petitioner in court of Sub-Divisional Judicial Magistrate, Diamond Harbour on 26th June 1973 in connection with the incident

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, the affidavit in reply filed on behalf of the State Government by the Secretary in the Department of Public Relations and Youth  1  1974 4 S.C.C. 1. 1000 Services, points out that in companynection with the incident set out in the grounds of detention a criminal case was filed in the companyrt of the Sub-, Divisional Judicial Magistrate, Diamond Harbour on 26th June, 1973

facts.text: Petitioner arrested in connection with the criminal case

anchor.surface_text: and he was arrested in companynection with that case,

facts.text: During investigation, witnesses unwilling to give evidence against petitioner and associates, criminal case decided to be dropped against petitioner

anchor.surface_text: but it appeared during investigation that witnesses were unwilling to give evidence in open companyrt against the petitioner and his associates and it was, therefore, felt that it was futile to proceed with the criminal case and it was decided to drop it against the petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioner was in jail on 29th December 1973 when detention order made

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was actually in jail on 29th December, 1973 when the order of detention was made

facts.text: Criminal case pending against petitioner on 3rd January 1974

anchor.surface_text: The record of the case which was produced before us by the learned companynsel appearing on behalf of the State showed that the criminal case was actually pending against the petitioner on. 3rd January, 1974.

facts.text: Criminal case dropped and petitioner discharged between 3rd January 1974 and 18th January 1974

anchor.surface_text: That means that the criminal case must have been dropped and the petitioner must have been discharged sometime between 3rd January, 1974 and 18th January, 1974, the latter being the date when he was once again arrested pursuant to the order of detention.

facts.text: Detention order passed in anticipation of petitioner being released from criminal case

anchor.surface_text: Now, if the criminal case were dropped, the petitioner would have to be released and in that event he would be free to carry on his nefarious activities. The District Magistrate, therefore, passed the order of detention on 29th December, 1973.

facts.text: 29th December 1973 was a Saturday, District Magistrate passed eight other detention orders that day

anchor.surface_text: He has pointed out that 29th December, 1973, which was the date when the order of detention was made, was a Saturday and on that day he had passed eight other orders of detention

facts.text: 30th December 1973 was a Sunday

anchor.surface_text: 30th December, 1973 was a Sunday and,

facts.text: District Magistrate busy with food procurement work on 31st December 1973, could not send report

anchor.surface_text: But the District Magistrate companyld number send the report on that day as he was very busy in companynection with food procurement work in the district

facts.text: 1st January 1974 was a public holiday

anchor.surface_text: and the next day, namely, 1st January, 1974 being a public holiday,

facts.text: Petitioner contends six month gap between incident and detention order makes satisfaction not genuine

anchor.surface_text: The first companytention urged Mr. Mukhoty, learned companynsel appearing amicus curiae on behalf of the petitioner, was that the solitary incident set out in the grounds of detention was so remote from the date of the order of detention-in fact there was a time lag about six months that the District Magistrate companyld number possibly have arrived at his subjective satisfaction on the basis of that incident.

facts.text: No other material prejudicial in petitioner's history sheet beyond grounds of detention

anchor.surface_text: We have looked at the history- sheet of the petitioner which was produced before us by the learned companynsel appearing on behalf of the State Government and we do number find any material prejudicial to the petitioner other than that set out in the grounds of detention.

concepts.interpretation: Not a mechanical test by counting months; depends on nature of acts, length of gap, reason for delay; must allow reasonable prognosis of future conduct; live link not snapped if act suggests ongoing course of conduct.

issues.text: Whether the solitary incident set out in the grounds of detention was so remote from the date of the order of detention, being a time lag of about six months, that the District Magistrate could not possibly have arrived at a real or genuine subjective satisfaction, lacking the requirement of proximity?

anchor.surface_text: The first contention urged Mr. Mukhoty, learned counsel appearing amicus curiae on behalf of the petitioner, was that the solitary incident set out in the grounds of detention was so remote from the date of the order of detention-in fact there was a time lag about six months that the District Magistrate could not possibly have arrived at his subjective satisfaction on the basis of that incident. The requirement of proximity, said Mr. Mukhoty, was not satisfied and the subjective satisfaction said to have been reached by the District Magistrate could not be regarded as real or genuine.

issues.text: Whether the incident set out in the grounds of detention merely affected maintenance of law and order without any impact on public order, lacking nexus with the subjective satisfaction for detention to prevent prejudicial acts to public order?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mukhoty on behalf of the petitioner then urged that even if the incident set out in the grounds of detention were true, it merely affected maintenance of law and order and did not have any impact on public order and hence there was no nexus between the act alleged against the petitioner and the subjective satisfaction reached by the District Magistrate.

issues.text: Whether the District Magistrate took into account other undisclosed material contained in the history sheet of the petitioner in arriving at his subjective satisfaction, denying effective representation and invalidating the detention order?

anchor.surface_text: Then it was contended on behalf of the petitioner that the District Magistrate had taken into account other material contained in the history sheet of the petitioner in arriving at his subjective satisfaction and since this material was not disclosed to the petitioner, he had no opportunity of making an effective representation and that the order of detention was, therefore, invalid.

issues.text: Whether the delay of twenty days between the making of the detention order on 29th December 1973 and the arrest on 18th January 1974 invalidated the order of detention?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mukhoty on behalf of the petitioner also tried to persuade us to strike down the order of detention on the ground that though the order of detention was made on 29th December, 1973, the petitioner was not arrested until 18th January, 1974 and there was thus a delay of twenty days in arresting the petitioner pursuant to the order of detention-

issues.text: Whether there was a violation of section 3 sub-section (3) due to delay of about five days in reporting the detention order to the State Government, and what is the true meaning and connotation of the word 'forthwith' as used therein?

anchor.surface_text: The last contention urged by Mr. Mukhoty on behalf of the petitioner was that though the order of detention was made on 29th December, 1973, he did not report the fact of the making of the order of detention to the State Government until 2nd January, 1974 and there was thus a delay of about five days which constituted a violation of the statutory requirement of section 3, sub- section (3) that the fact of the making of the order of detention must be reported forthwith to the State Government. This contention raises the question as to what is the true meaning and connotation of the word forthwith as used in section 3 sub-section (3).

arguments.claim: The solitary incident set out in the grounds of detention was so remote from the date of the order of detention (time lag of about six months) that the District Magistrate could not possibly have arrived at his subjective satisfaction on the basis of that incident; requirement of proximity not satisfied; subjective satisfaction not real or genuine

anchor.surface_text: The first contention urged Mr. Mukhoty, learned counsel appearing amicus curiae on behalf of the petitioner, was that the solitary incident set out in the grounds of detention was so remote from the date of the order of detention-in fact there was a time lag about six months that the District Magistrate could not possibly have arrived at his subjective satisfaction on the basis of that incident. The requirement of proximity, said Mr. Mukhoty, was not satisfied and the subjective satisfaction said to have been reached by the District Magistrate could not be regarded as real or genuine.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: made and it was only on some date between 3rd January, 1974 and 18th January, 1974 that lie was released and then once again arrested on 18th January,

arguments.court_reasoning: Delay not unreasonable; explained by petitioner being in jail on criminal case until between 3-18 Jan 1974

arguments.claim: Delay of five days in reporting detention order to State Government (made 29 Dec 1973, reported 2 Jan 1974) violates s.3(3) MISA requirement to report 'forthwith'

anchor.surface_text: The last contention urged by Mr. Mukhoty on behalf of the petitioner was that though the order of detention was made on 29th December, 1973, he did not report the fact of the making of the order of detention to the State Government until 2nd January, 1974 and there was thus a delay of about five days which constituted a violation of the statutory requirement of section 3, sub- section (3) that the fact of the making of the order of detention must be reported forthwith to the State Government.

arguments.court_reasoning: 'Forthwith' means with all reasonable despatch without avoidable delay; delay justified by Saturday (8 detentions), Sunday, busy with food procurement 31 Dec, public holiday 1 Jan; prompt despatch

arguments.claim: Criminal case filed re incident, but witnesses unwilling due to fear, case dropped; detention passed in anticipation of release to prevent further nefarious activities

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, the affidavit in reply filed on behalf of the State Government by the Secretary... a criminal case was filed... witnesses were unwilling... decided to drop it against the petitioner. Now, if the criminal case were dropped, the petitioner would have to be released... District Magistrate, therefore, passed the order of detention on 29th December, 1973.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he order of detention on 29th December, 1973. The order of detention was in fact passed in anticipation of the petitioner being released as a result o

arguments.court_reasoning: Maintains live link despite time gap; case pending until early Jan 1974

arguments.claim: District Magistrate could not report earlier: 29 Dec Saturday with 8 other detentions (typing delay), 30 Dec Sunday, 31 Dec busy food procurement, 1 Jan holiday; reported 2 Jan

anchor.surface_text: He has pointed out that 29th December, 1973... was a Saturday and on that day he had passed eight other orders of detention... 30th December, 1973 was a Sunday... 31st December... busy in connection with food procurement... 1st January, 1974 being a public holiday... sent the report only on 2nd January, 1974.

arguments.court_reasoning: Sufficient explanation; acted with reasonable despatch, no avoidable delay

arguments.claim: Proximity test requires live link; not mechanical by months; depends on nature of acts, gap, delay reasons; here dacoity nature suggests ongoing course, not isolated

anchor.surface_text: Now it is true... there must be a live link... test of proximity is not a rigid or mechanical test... prejudicial act... part of an organised operation... daring act of dacoity... work of a habituated and hardened criminal.

arguments.claim: Act affects public order not mere law and order: dacoity with lethal weapons, indiscriminate firing, deaths, panic, insecurity disturbs even tempo of community life

anchor.surface_text: Now, there can be no doubt... distinction... Public order is the even tempo... act of dacoity created a panic... seriously disturbed the even tempo... nexus with... public order.

arguments.claim: No undisclosed material: history-sheet checked, nothing prejudicial beyond grounds

anchor.surface_text: We have looked at the history-sheet... do not find any material prejudicial... other than that set out in the grounds of detention.

arguments.claim: 'Forthwith' in s.3(3) means with all reasonable despatch, without avoidable delay; follows precedent from Preventive Detention Act case

anchor.surface_text: The question is fortunately not res integra... Keshav Nilkanth Joglekar... 'forthwith' must be... done with all reasonable despatch and without avoidable delay.

holdings.text: There is no hard and fast rule that merely because there is a time lag of about six months between the offending acts and the date of the order of detention, the causal link must be taken to be broken and the satisfaction claimed to have been arrived at by the District Magistrate must be regarded as sham or unreal; the test of proximity is not a rigid or mechanical test; here the live link exists due to the nature of the dacoity and the pending criminal case.

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore numberhard and fast rule that merely because there is a time lag of about six months between the offending acts and the date of the order of detention, the causal link must be taken to be broken and the satisfaction claimed to have been arrived at by the District Magistrate must be regarded as sham or unreal. Whether the acts of the detenu

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proximity test depends on nature of acts (dacoity suggests ongoing criminal course), reasons for delay (pending criminal case dropped recently), allowing prognosis of future conduct; precedents like Golam Hussain and Lakshman Khatik followed.

holdings.text: The act alleged affected public order, not merely law and order; there was nexus between the act and the subjective satisfaction for detention to prevent acts prejudicial to public order.

anchor.surface_text: Now, there can be numberdoubt that the acts of the detenu on which a subjective satisfaction is claimed to have been reached by the detaining authority must have relevance to the formation of such subjective satisfaction. If the acts of the detenu relied. on by the detaining authority are irrelevant, numberreasonable person

holdings.reasoning_summary: Degree of disturbance determines public order vs law/order; dacoity at night with arms, firing, deaths, panic disturbed even tempo of community life; Arun Ghosh precedent applied.

holdings.text: No material other than that set out in the grounds of detention was taken into account by the District Magistrate in reaching his subjective satisfaction; history-sheet contains no other prejudicial material.

anchor.surface_text: Then it was companytended on behalf of the petitioner that the District Magistrate had taken into account other material companytained in the history sheet of the petitioner in arriving at his subjective satisfaction and since this material was number disclosed to the petitioner, he had numberopportunity of making an effective representation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court examined history-sheet produced; no undisclosed prejudicial material found beyond grounds served to detenu.

holdings.text: The delay of twenty days between the detention order and arrest is not unreasonable and is sufficiently explained by the petitioner being in jail on the criminal case until shortly before arrest.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mukhoty on behalf of the petitioner also tried to persuade us to strike down the order of detention on the ground that though the order of detention was made on 29th December, 1973, the petitioner was number arrested until 18th January, 1974 and there was thus a delay of twenty days in arresting the petitioner pursuant to the order

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delay not fatal absent unreasonableness; explained by petitioner's incarceration in related criminal case until between 3-18 Jan 1974.

holdings.text: The District Magistrate sent the report to the State Government forthwith as required by section 3(3) MISA; 'forthwith' means with all reasonable despatch and without avoidable delay, and the five-day interval was justified.
holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Forthwith' interpreted per Keshav Nilkanth precedent; delay due to Saturday (multiple detentions, typing), Sunday, food procurement workload on 31 Dec, holiday 1 Jan; no avoidable delay.

precedents.citation: Golam Hussain v. The Commissioner of Police, Calcutta Oi-.v. 1 1974 4 S.C C. 530

anchor.surface_text: Golam Hussain v. The Commissioner of Police, Calcutta Oi-.v.  1 1974 4 S.C C. 530. 99 9 detention, namely, inhibition of prejudicial activity of the species specified in the statute.

precedents.case_name: Golam Hussain v Commissioner of Police Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: there must be a live link between the grounds of criminal activity alleged by the detaining authority and the purpose of detention; credible chain snapped if too long and unexplained interval between offending acts and order of detention

precedents.citation: Lakshman Khatik v.State of West Bengal 1 1974 4 S.C.C. 1

anchor.surface_text: Such is the ratio of proximity in Lakshman Khatik v.State of West Bengal 1 . No authority, acting rationally, can be satisfied, subjectively or otherwise, of future mischief merely because long ago the detenu had done something evil. To rule otherwise is to sanction a simulacrum of a statutory requirement. But no mechanical test by counting the months of the interval is sound. 1 1974 4 S.C.C. 1. 1000

precedents.case_name: Lakshman Khatik v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: ratio of proximity: no authority can be satisfied of future mischief merely because long ago the detenu had done something evil

precedents.citation: Arun Ghosh v. State of West Bengal 1 -19703 S. C. R. 288

anchor.surface_text: Arun Ghosh v. State of West Bengal.  1  The learned Chief Justice pointed out in that case the difference between maintenance of law and order and its disturbance and the maintenance of public order and its disturbance in the following words  1 -19703 S. C. R. 288 1001 Public order was said to embrace more of the community than law and order.

precedents.case_name: Arun Ghosh v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between maintenance of law and order and public order: public order embraces more of the community; degree of disturbance determines if it's law/order or public order
precedents.cited_holding: Public order is the even tempo of the life of the community... disturbance of public order distinguished from acts against individuals

precedents.citation: Keshav Nilkanth Joglekar v. The Commissioner of Police, Greater Bombay 1 1956 S. C. R. 653

anchor.surface_text: Keshav Nilkanth Joglekar v. The Commissioner of Police, Greater Bombay.  1  The statutory provision which came up for consideration in that case was section 3, sub-section  3  of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950 which contained an identical provision as section 3. subsection  3  of the present Act... 1 1956 S. C. R. 653. 1003

precedents.case_name: Keshav Nilkanth Joglekar v Commissioner of Police Greater Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of 'forthwith' in section 3(3): done with all reasonable despatch and without avoidable delay
precedents.cited_holding: report sent forthwith if sent at earliest possible time, without avoidable delay

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: Whilst taking this view on facts, we do not wish to underscore the need for strict compliance with this requirement of section 3, sub-section 3 . It is a very important requirement intended to secure that the State Government shall have sufficient time for consideration before it decides-and this decision has to be made within twelve days of the making of the order of detention-whether or not to approve the order of detention and the Court would, therefore, insist on strict compliance with it and not condone avoidable delay, even if it be trivial But in the present case the facts stated by the District Magistrate in his affidavit show that be acted with prompt despatch and was not guilty of any avoidable delay. The District Magistrate must, therefore, be held to have sent the report forthwith as required by section 3, sub- section 3 .

outcome.relief_summary: All contentions against the detention order rejected; detention upheld

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore numberhard and fast rule that merely because there is a time lag of about six months between the offending acts and the date of the order of detention, the causal link must be taken to be broken and the satisfaction claimed to have been arrived at by the District Magistrate must be regarded as sham or unreal. Whether the acts of the detenu

Whilst taking this view on facts, we do not wish to underscore the need for strict compliance with this requirement of section 3, sub-section 3 . It is a very important requirement intended to secure that the State Government shall have sufficient time for consideration before it decides-and this decision has to be made within twelve days of the making of the order of detention-whether or not to approve the order of detention and the Court would, therefore, insist on strict compliance with it and not condone avoidable delay, even if it be trivial But in the present case the facts stated by the District Magistrate in his affidavit show that be acted with prompt despatch and was not guilty of any avoidable delay. The District Magistrate must, therefore, be held to have sent the report forthwith as required by section 3, sub- section 3 .

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mukhoty on behalf of the petitioner also tried to persuade us to strike down the order of detention on the ground that though the order of detention was made on 29th December, 1973, the petitioner was number arrested until 18th January, 1974 and there was thus a delay of twenty days in arresting the petitioner pursuant to the order

Whilst taking this view on facts, we do not wish to underscore the need for strict compliance with this requirement of section 3, sub-section 3 . It is a very important requirement intended to secure that the State Government shall have sufficient time for consideration before it decides-and this decision has to be made within twelve days of the making of the order of detention-whether or not to approve the order of detention and the Court would, therefore, insist on strict compliance with it and not condone avoidable delay, even if it be trivial But in the present case the facts stated by the District Magistrate in his affidavit show that be acted with prompt despatch and was not guilty of any avoidable delay. The District Magistrate must, therefore, be held to have sent the report forthwith as required by section 3, sub- section 3 .

edges.explanation: The holding constrains the scope of 'forthwith' in c10 to a narrower constitutional interpretation ('with all reasonable despatch and without avoidable delay'), enabling reading down without rewriting the provision.
